nodes.text: Probability weighting (the inverse-S relation between decision weights w and declared probabilities p) can be mechanistically explained by a decision maker having greater uncertainty about outcome distributions than a disinterested observer because the decision maker must estimate probabilities from finite time series while the observer knows or assumes probabilities a priori

Context: 'probabilities' p(x) are the numbers specified by a disinterested observer (DO) and 'decision weights' w(x) are the numbers inferred from a decision maker's (DM) behaviour in the DO's behavioural model

Empirical claim: the robust experimental finding is that decision weights w(x) exceed probabilities p(x) for extreme (rare) events and, through normalization, are lower for common events, producing an inverse-S shape when plotting cumulative decision weights Fw against cumulative probabilities Fp

Claim / Mechanism: if a DM assumes a larger scale (greater variance) or different location for the same unimodal distribution than the DO, mapping the DM's CDF Fw(x) against the DO's CDF Fp(x) yields an inverse-S curve; differences in shape parameters (e.g. t-distribution degrees of freedom) produce similar effects

Claim: estimating probabilities from finite time series produces larger relative estimation uncertainty for rare events than for common events (absolute error decreases but relative error increases as p decreases)

Claim: conceptual difference between DO and DM perspectives arises because DO often reasons about ensemble probabilities while DM reasons about time evolution of their own outcomes (ergodicity); non-ergodic processes like multiplicative growth make rare events and fluctuations consequential for DM but less so for DO

Method: analytic derivation for Gaussian case shows w(x) = Gaussian with scale alpha times DO's scale, elimination of (x-mu)^2 yields w(p) proportional to p^{1/alpha^2} times a normalizing prefactor, explaining inverse-S when alpha>1

Method: formalization of DM conservatism by adding standard error to estimated density: w(x) = [p_hat(x) + epsilon[p_hat(x)]] / integral, with epsilon scaling like sqrt(p_hat(x)/(T delta x)), so correction vanishes as sample size grows

Evidence / Scaling argument: for counts n(x) in bin width delta x over T observations, p_hat(x)=n/(T delta x) and standard error epsilon[p_hat] = sqrt(p_hat/(T delta x)), so relative error ~ 1/sqrt(p_hat T delta x) increases as p_hat decreases

Result / Evidence: analytic plots and figures (Gaussian and t-distribution examples) show that larger DM scale or added conservative correction produce the inverse-S mapping between Fw and Fp, reproducing qualitative features reported in prospect theory

Method / Simulation: simulate DM counting outcomes in finite series, estimate p_hat per bin, compute uncertainty numerically across repetitions, set w by adding one standard error and normalizing (Eq.13/14); apply to Gaussian and fat-tailed t data

Result / Evidence: simulations using finite observation series for Gaussian and t-distributions produce noisy but clear inverse-S curves when DM uses conservative weights; effect stronger for fat-tailed distributions; supports mechanistic origin from estimation uncertainty and time-perspective

Evidence / Model fitting: fitting Gaussian and t-distribution models (location and scale/shape parameters) to experimental data from Tversky and Kahneman (1992) and Tversky and Fox (1995) produces good fits comparable to standard phenomenological weighting functions (TK and Lattimore forms)

Conclusion: probability weighting can be interpreted as a principled, cautious adjustment by DMs to account for estimation uncertainty and time-based exposure rather than necessarily a cognitive bias or irrational error by DMs; inverse-S merely indicates model disagreement

Limitation / Assumption: the mechanistic model requires assumptions that DO and DM use different models and that the DM adopts a specific conservative correction (adding standard error); fits to data are not unique and phenomenological fits remain indistinguishable within standard errors
